Whenne him who for his Doughtir dyed,</br>Quelling a leude base losell's pryde,</br>This londe grown slombrous schall foryitt</br>Maydennes schall heare with dradde of PITT.
Whenne this rude mace which me hath smote</br>Calls ydlers on a Show to glote</br>SIXTEENE a-new dismaye shall frit</br>And shee schall shrinke at syght of PITT.
Whenne Englond woxen osere schall bee</br>Yil starr'd by londe bot haut by see</br>A fearful loade her polle schall splitt</br>While Sixteene quakes at name of PYTTE.
Of him it needes hir littel fears</br>But lightly doth he heed hir yeeres</br>Send not Polle-clippers where unfitte</br>Sixteene thee prieth, Maister PYTTE.
Ne King mare staide, ne sadderre Queene</br>Ne Maydes mare faire, ne Clerks mare teen</br>Ne words mare glibbe were sedde or writt</br>Thanne whenne Sixteene schall stert at PYTTE.
The daies of knyghtnoode auide bin gon</br>Yet Sixteene hath hir Chaumpyonn</br>And yll at reste mies Goste schall flitt</br>In Sixteene rue of Maister PYTTE.
Ah ne'er mote gatherers rude and base</br>With shame caste donne the Mayden's face,</br>To proven giffe meet for Polle as yett</br>Warne thee Polle-pillours Maistre PYTTE.</br>
